newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: RUGBY UNION-Vidiri says vindicated by selection.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-Vidiri says vindicated by selection.

text.p: Selection in the New Zealand Barbarians rugby team for a two-match tour of Britain next month was a huge relief to Counties-Manukau winger Joeli Vidiri.
Being named in the 23-strong tour squad this week vindicated his decision to turn his back on his native Fiji and switch his allegiance to New Zealand.
Vidiri parted ways with the Fiji Rugby Football Union more than two years ago, saying that Counties were prepared to invest more time and effort into him.
His decision caused consternation in Fiji and the pressure went on him to return.
Vidiri, 23, ignored the pressure but even this year he has received unsubtle reminders from some Fijian players they think he should be playing for Fiji.
Fijian representatives -- King Country fullback Phillipe Rayasi, Waikato wing Aisea Tuilevu and Waikato hooker Greg Smith -- have all gone out of their way to deliver the message, on the field.
Vidiri, though, is comfortable with his decision, even more so now that he has been included in the Barbarians team.
It seemed an All Blacks jersey beckoned when he was named in the All Blacks squad last year.

But Vidiri's promotion was stalled when the International Rugby Board (IRB) ruled he had to serve a three-year stand-down period before being eligible to play for another country. He is not eligible for All Blacks selection until April 1998.
"That part's been frustrating, sometimes it was really hard," Vidiri said.
"I just couldn't sit still and watch last year's World Cup, I just kept thinking that I really wanted to be there with them."

When he was named in the New Zealand Barbarians team this week to tour Britain, along with another player who is affected by the same IRB rule -- Auckland's Dylan Mika -- Vidiri said his decision finally felt right.
"I'm really happy to be picked for the Barbarians. I know now that my decision to go with New Zealand was the right one," he said.
"It feels like everything has been worthwhile."
